H0.text: A nucleus is the cellular structure shared by organisms in the kingdoms Eubacteria, Archaebacteria, and Protista.

H1.text: A cell membrane is the cellular structure common to organisms in the kingdoms Eubacteria, Archaebacteria, and Protista.

H2.text: A circular chromosome is the cellular structure that organisms in the kingdoms Eubacteria, Archaebacteria, and Protista have in common.

H3.text: A mitochondrion is the cellular structure that organisms in the kingdoms Eubacteria, Archaebacteria, and Protista have in common.

A4.text: In eukaryotic cells, the nuclear membrane separates the contents of the nucleus from the cytoplasm of the cell.

A5.text: Endosymbiotic theory proposes that through the course of evolution, a eukaryotic cell engulfed these two types of bacteria, leading to the formation of mitochondria and chloroplasts inside eukaryotic cells.

A6.text: Eukaryotic cells possess a membrane-bound nucleus, and prokaryotic cells lack a nucleus but have a nucleoid region.

A7.text: The DNA is contained in a circular chromosome in direct contact with the cytoplasm, in a region known as the nucleoid.
